div.head: MODERN HELLENISM.
div.p: It is no infrequent error of an over-civilized age to depreciate all times and nations, which do not appear either to meet its immediate wants or to be limited by the same theories of action and speculation which confine itself. But this vice of thought is one which we should scarcely expect to find in those who assume the place of guides to the popular opinion, and leaders of the intellect of the day. It proves a narrow and morbid tone of mind, which at once disqualifies a man for occupying any such position.

We have been lately informed, and that by no slight authority, that the proper work of a Poet as teacher, is to deliver the intellect of his age from all undue influences of habit and example, and to lead it back to purer fountains than slake its daily thirst of knowledge. To do this, we are told, he must be adequate to his time. Thus far, few will dissent from the propositions laid down. But we next discover, that the most perfect instance on record of an age for whom this office was fulfilled by its leaders of thought, is the age of Pericles. To substantiate this assertion, we are greeted with the somewhat gratituous information, that it was an age of supreme refinement; a statement which has at least one merit—it is impossible to impugn it. We are, however, left to take it for granted that this quality is, for our's and for all ages, the one supremely desirable and necessary.

Sophocles and Thucydides are chosen as presenting, on the whole, the most perfect examples of Hellenic intellect; and the inferiority of all other minds is rapidly assumed. The peculiarities of this deified intellect are then discussed with brief eloquence. It is stated to be in cast of thought essentially modern—analytic and inductive in history, serene and graceful in poetry. A parallel is then sketched, we cannot but think with undue haste between the age in question and that of Elizabeth. Every Athenian, we are given to understand, possessed a distinct and delicate appreciation of the highest national intellects. The poet and the historian were merely the outcome, each in his own way, of the general popular feeling,—the representatives of somewhat more than the average Greek power of mind—differing, in short, from the mass of the educated people, rather in quantity than in quality of intellect. The Elizabethans, on the other hand, could not produce anything like a man of mind equal to the average ability of Athens. In their best moments the leaders of English thought and action were unable to attain the ordinary height of a Grecian citizen. Sir Walter Raleigh is the man selected to prove this assertion. This is at least bold; a man who strikes at Raleigh cannot be accused of hawking at small game.

It is far from the intention of the present writer, even did his space allow it, to enter into an elaborate vindication of Raleigh’s character and intellect. The contemptuous laughter of the Oxford theatre will not outweigh the memory of a life, the noblest perhaps among the men of a great age. Raleigh in his time outlived worse things than that; Cecil and Coke were enemies more perilous than an eloquent Professor of the art (or science) of Poetry. To hold him up to the scorn of sciolists and the ridicule of fools, as a mere declaimer on empty questions in an irrational style, may be very amusing—if so, it will not fail of its appropriate reward from the Undergraduate’s gallery— but it will convince no man of the lecturer’s candour or of the force of his argument. If indeed any one seriously desires to see the question of Raleigh’s life and its work fully and wisely treated, in a spirit of no irrational reverence, we refer him, certain that he will be in no wise disappointed, to the noble and un- answerable vindication of Mr. Kingsley.

But the matter lies far deeper than this. It will require more proof than we have yet received to make us believe that the age which culminated in the yet more shameful than mournful ruin of the Syracusan expedition, was for practical purpose and labour superior to that which attained its consumma- tion in the defeat of the Spanish Armada. Let us see what each age left to its successors. The one, a civilization consumed by sloth and selfishness to the core—the other, a nation so organised as to resist the influence even of Stuart tyranny and Stuart baseness, in the consciousness that under Elizabeth it had seen established in Europe, first and for ever, the right of political freedom as the secret of political strength. The one generation, scoffed at by the very poet who helped to brutalize it, left its successors to sink under a disgraceful tyranny; the very recollection of the other paved the way to the establishment of the noblest Republic the world has yet seen. After Pericles came Critias— after Elizabeth, Cromwell.

Let us take the two men respectively offered as specimens. Raleigh is no more to be judged solely by his literary works, noble as they are, than his works are to be judged by a few detached passages of inferior importance, which, at worst, can only prove that he saw no further than his rival on points not yet cleared up.* He was the founder of a nation, the valiant and laborious worker in newly-discovered lands, hemmed round with circumstances where he had all to fight against and nothing to uphold him but the 'vivida vis animi';—the resolution of his mighty heart and mind
div.quote: To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.
div.p: To his wise counsel Elizabeth, who might have known, attributed in main part the glorious deed of July, 1588. Thucydides’ sole campaign was a dishonourable failure. It is not merely unjust—it is simply absurd, to omit all consideration of such facts as these in an elaborate parallel of one man with another. If indeed Raleigh be the ancient and Thucydides the modern, there is more reason than we had believed in the aspi- ration of minor poets for a time far removed from 'these bad days’, this strange disease of modern life.”

Was Bacon in physical science inferior to the men of the age of Pericles? was Was the refined contraction of the Hellenic drama a more adequate type of the generation of Sophocles, than Shakespeare of the Elizabethans? It may be that we have been hitherto mistaken; but we must have more than the measured rhetoric of a lecture to prove that we must resign the heroes of our own history for the idols of Oxford Hellenism.

list.item: The attack is most peculiarly unfair, inasmuch as it represents the histories of Raleigh and Thucydides as works of like aim, and having first assumed this, proceeds to ridicule the one for being unlike the other.
